commands.name: Step 1: Deploy Application with Auto-Sync
commands.command: kubectl apply -f argocd-scenarios/12-disaster-recovery/application.yaml && echo 'Deploying with auto-sync and self-heal enabled...' && sleep 15 && kubectl get application sc12-disaster-recovery -n argocd
commands.description: Deploy the application with auto-sync and self-healing enabled
commands.explanation: This Application has automated sync with selfHeal:true and prune:true. This means ArgoCD will automatically restore any deleted or modified resources to match the Git state. This is the foundation of GitOps disaster recovery.
commands.what_it_does: Creates the ArgoCD Application with full auto-sync capabilities.

commands.name: Step 2: Verify Application is Healthy
commands.command: kubectl get deployment,service,configmap -n argocd-sc-12 && echo '' && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-12 && echo '' && kubectl get application sc12-disaster-recovery -n argocd -o jsonpath='Health: {.status.health.status}, Sync: {.status.sync.status}'
commands.description: Verify all resources are deployed and healthy
commands.explanation: You should see 3 running pods, a service, a configmap, and the application showing Healthy/Synced. This is our baseline 'good state' stored in Git.
commands.what_it_does: Lists all deployed resources and application status.
commands.next_step: Simulate disaster: delete a critical resource.

commands.name: Step 3: Simulate Disaster - Delete Deployment
commands.command: echo '>>> DISASTER: Accidentally deleting the deployment! <<<' && kubectl delete deployment dr-app -n argocd-sc-12 && echo 'Deployment deleted! All pods are gone!' && echo '' && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-12
commands.description: Simulate accidental deletion of the deployment
commands.explanation: Someone accidentally ran 'kubectl delete deployment' in production. All pods are immediately terminated. Without GitOps, this would require finding and re-applying the correct manifests manually.
commands.what_it_does: Deletes the deployment, simulating a production incident.

commands.name: Step 4: Watch ArgoCD Auto-Recovery
commands.command:
echo '>>> Watch ArgoCD restore the deployment <<<
>>> Open ArgoCD UI at http://localhost:30800 to see it in real-time <<<' && echo '' && echo 'Waiting for ArgoCD self-heal (up to 30 seconds)...' && sleep 20 && echo '=== After ArgoCD Recovery ===' && kubectl get deployment -n argocd-sc-12 && echo '' && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-12
commands.description: Watch ArgoCD automatically restore the deleted deployment
commands.explanation: Because selfHeal is enabled, ArgoCD detects the drift (deployment missing from cluster but present in Git) and automatically re-creates it. Within seconds, the deployment and pods are restored. No manual intervention needed!
commands.what_it_does: Waits for ArgoCD to detect and fix the drift.
commands.next_step: Simulate a bigger disaster: delete the entire namespace.

commands.name: Step 5: Verify Recovery Complete
commands.command: kubectl get application sc12-disaster-recovery -n argocd -o jsonpath='Health: {.status.health.status}, Sync: {.status.sync.status}' && echo '' && echo '' && kubectl get all -n argocd-sc-12
commands.explanation: The application should be back to Healthy/Synced. All 3 pods are running again. ArgoCD restored everything from Git automatically. The recovery time depends on the sync interval (default: 3 minutes) or self-heal check.
commands.what_it_does: Verifies complete recovery of all resources.

commands.name: Step 6: Simulate Disaster - Delete Service and ConfigMap
commands.command: echo '>>> DISASTER: Deleting service AND configmap! <<<' && kubectl delete service dr-service -n argocd-sc-12 && kubectl delete configmap dr-content -n argocd-sc-12 && echo 'Service and ConfigMap deleted!' && echo '' && kubectl get svc,cm -n argocd-sc-12
commands.explanation: This simulates a more severe incident where multiple resources are deleted. ArgoCD will detect all missing resources and restore them all in a single sync operation.
commands.what_it_does: Deletes the service and configmap to simulate multi-resource failure.

commands.name: Step 7: Watch Multi-Resource Recovery
commands.command: echo 'Waiting for ArgoCD self-heal...' && sleep 25 && echo '=== Recovered Resources ===' && kubectl get deployment,service,configmap -n argocd-sc-12 -l app=dr-app && echo '' && kubectl get application sc12-disaster-recovery -n argocd -o jsonpath='Health: {.status.health.status}, Sync: {.status.sync.status}'
commands.description: Verify ArgoCD restored both the service and configmap
commands.explanation: ArgoCD restored both resources in a single sync. This demonstrates that GitOps provides a complete disaster recovery mechanism. As long as your Git repo is intact, your entire infrastructure can be rebuilt.
commands.what_it_does: Verifies recovery of all deleted resources.
commands.next_step: Scenario complete! Clean up when ready.

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete Application
commands.command: kubectl delete application sc12-disaster-recovery -n argocd 2>/dev/null; kubectl delete namespace argocd-sc-12 --ignore-not-found
commands.description: Remove all resources from this scenario
commands.explanation: Removes the ArgoCD Application and namespace. Since the Application has prune enabled, deleting the Application via ArgoCD UI would also clean up resources.
commands.what_it_does: Cleans up all disaster recovery scenario resources.
